intro: Saracha conspersa, commonly known as the hairy saracha, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely hairy stems and leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Saracha conspersa thrives in temperate climates and is often found in rocky or gravelly soils. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
